posts.author: Theophilus Fist
posts.content:
Being a relative newbie to character building, I've been discovering things about the game that most of you have known for a decade.  My current kick is to make builds that exceed the +20 AB cap.  In reading the NWNWiki, I saw that Improved Disarm has a -4 attack penalty, while offering a +4 bonus per category of size difference.  So wielding a large weapon against a medium weapon there is no penalty to attempt disarm, against small weapons there is a +4 bonus and against tiny weapons there is a +8 bonus.  .

I made a meleer wielding a two-hander and he is making mince meat out of opponents with smaller weapons when using ID.  Maybe he would even without ID, but it seems like the AB bonus in those instances is too good to be true.  Meanwhile, I don't see a lot of melee builds that include the feat.  Is there some reason more melee builds don't include it (especially given that it bypasses the AB cap)?

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
It's a matter of feats and priority mostly, improved knockdown has priority over improved disarm for disabling mages and thieves and has to be taken first. After that you may not have the available feats for that, not everybody is a fighter/ xx/ champion of torm build anyway. But after all is said and done it is also a matter of playing style. Most people tend to play defensively, so when they have to go without the shield's armour class (wog and sinfar aside) they want to see a really good benefit for that and not just a situational AB boost.

Those things, don't change the fact that iimproved disarm is an awesome feat though. Take it whenever you can.

See here also, i am talking about it => http://nwnecbguild.forumer.com/topic/23 ... DfoMRZIrhQ

posts.content: Thanks - in playing my meleer. IKD is a much more necessary feat to drop casters, etc., when leveling.

posts.author: darktooth
posts.content: A simple question, can a dual-wielder be disarmed of two weapons at once? What if the two weapons are of different sizes?

posts.author: Yunim
posts.content: (Improved) Disarm only targets the weapon in the target's right/main hand. If you get disarmed twice in a row then you will lose both weapons, but you will only lose one weapon per Disarm.

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Greetings Theophilus Fist!

Improved disarm is a fabulous feat for any strength two handed build (or two bladed sword/double axe/dire mace), if you can spare the feats, exactly as Valerfor writes.
I agree it is very underrated and should be used more. In fact I believe any serious two handed strength fighter build should try to get improved disarm.
It makes you feel like any non-spellcaster who doesnt bring a proper (large) weapon to a fight with you is not worthy of truly battling you.
Smack that weapon out of their hand! Show me a proper weapon :)

It is basically a free disarm attempt for anyone who is not using a large weapon, fists, or a creature weapon. Plus one gets bonus +4 and +8 AB if they are using a small or tiny weapon. That bonus AB is also added to threat rolls, so you also have an additional chance to critical hit. One gets attacks of opportunity if NPC enemies are disarmed and not wearing gloves. Ordinary fists also struggle to penetrate damage reduction unless they are a monk or are wearing monk gloves. That ghostly visage becomes very high value all of a sudden. The feat also makes one change their cognitive strategy against rogue enemies. Without improved disarm one might try to knock them down or at least attack them so they don't sneak you to death. With Improved disarm one is spamming that feat as soon as a rogue with a knife turns up. Sometimes I am hoping the disarm attempt fails so I can continue to have that sweet sweet +4-8 AB :)

I agree with Valerfor that Blind Fight, Knockdown and Improved Knockdown are higher on the priority list than Improved Disarm.
Therefore feats become a problem and I've struggled to find a way to put improved disarm into builds without bonus combat feats, ie without Fighter or CoT, it is just far too much of a compromise and there arent enough feats.
But in any two handed strength fighter build, I try to get it with all the bonus feats available. 

I think The Charnel Lord is a nice example of very good usage of the Improved Disarm feat. Palemaster builds have amazing defensive abilities but are hard to get the AB up compared with others, the improved disarm plus large weapon helps balance the build out quite nicely, plus the extra AB helps with devastating critical attempts :)

Regarding exceeding the +20 AB Cap, there was a competition in the ECB many years back to try to get the highest melee AB possible in a single attack. Improved Disarm featured, along with cheesy Druid levels for extra AB outdoors, Weapon Master 28, Paladin for Taunt and Smite Evil for extra bonus AB was also used. 

Here's a few posts from the ages:
Strength Highest Possible Melee AB by Mithdradates
Dexterity Highest Possible Melee AB by Grimnir77

Hope that helps with some insight into this feat, it is definitely one of my favorites

posts.author: Yunim
posts.content:
The AB effects of Disarm will remain even if the target can't be disarmed.

The only way to make a creature immune to Disarm is to curse their weapon. This prevents the Disarm from working at all but the AB effect will remain.

I just did some testing with a few different cases.
By default creatures are not disarmable, which means that they can lose their weapon to Disarm but they won't drop it. To make a disarmed weapon drop the creature must be disarmable and the weapon must be droppable, which requires changing the default settings. So making Disarm work on NPCs the same way it works for PCs is a conscious choice on the part of the module's creator.
If the creator chooses to make the creature immune to Disarm then they have to curse the weapon in the creature's right hand, so that is also a conscious choice.

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
Most designers will only mark certain creatures/NPCs undisarmable if they are using weapons that are "too powerful" for the PW setting.

I see this type of stuff all the time in Mods that I take apart to look at things in them, or to alter them if I dislike what I am experiencing.

Looking in the toolset, I see that these Duergar are equipped with two Scimitars + 5.  That may be why they are not Disarmable.

Disarm is still usable (Improved Disarm, that is) if one is either using a two-handed weapon OR is sizes bigger (like a Dragon).  It will give AB according to the size difference of the weapon(s) in question.  So if the opponent is using a tiny weapon, for example, the bonus will be +8 to AB.  That is pretty nice.

I'm curious about the Dragon here.  If one has Improved Disarm and goes into Dragon Shape, what bonus does one get then?  The NWN Wiki says that Creature Weapons here are of the size catagory of the Creature in question.  the NWN Wiki says that Dragons are of Huge size. This is very interesting
Attempting a disarm applies a -6 penalty to the character's attack roll, and the combatant with the larger weapon gains a +4 bonus per size category of difference.
Since the Creature weapon is dependent on the size of the Creature, and Dragon Shape is Huge (one catagory higher than Large), that should be a bonus of 4 size catagories vs Tiny!!!  That would be +12 -4 = +8 to AB for Improved Disarm!!!!

It could be a way to dramatically increase AB in Dragon Shape.

Has anyone tried testing this?

posts.author: Yunim
posts.content:
While attempting to test this I encountered a bug with NWN EE (v80.8193.13). It seems that Knockdown and Improved Knockdown are not selectable feats on Monk levels.
Can someone else confirm if they also experience this bug please.

I tested a Human/Dragon with Improved Disarm vs a Halfling. Weapons used were Dagger (Tiny), Kama (Small), and Scimitar (Medium).
Dragon AB: +56. Dragon ID AB vs Dagger: +52. Dragon ID AB vs Scimitar: +52. Dragon ID vs Unarmed: +52.
Human Kama AB: +34. Human Kama ID AB vs Dagger: +34.
Human Scimitar AB: +35. Human Scimitar ID AB vs Dagger: +39.

So Dragon Shape users will have a -4 AB penalty when using Improved Disarm regardless of the target's weapon size.
However, Dragon Shape counts as unarmed when using Improved Disarm so disarmed weapons go straight to the disarmer's inventory instead of to the ground.
